content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really good idea for a clash of code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Doable in less than 5 minutes even if a bit math-heavy for clash of code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Relatively math-heavy puzzle but overall very instructive
Could you clarify that the path Bob is running on is a straight line? I mistook the "path" to be the perimeter of the right triangle, instead of just the hypotenuse.

Goal
* Please delete the last sentence.

Output
* Please change the last sentence to:
The format should be [[hours]]{{:}}[[minutes]], with [[hours]] and [[minutes]] zero-padded to two digits if they are single-digit after rounding.

Constraints
* Please change 1e9 to 10⁹ for clarity.

Cases
* Please revise the cases where any intermediate calculated value or final output exceeds 2**53 because not all programming languages on the CG platform can handle arbitrarily large numbers.

Thanks.
Fixed.

Please also check on the order of operations between dividing the distance by the speed and multiplying the distance by 60 (converting from hour to minute). I get a different answer for one of the test cases when flipping the operation order.

My Python code:
distance = math.sqrt(a * a + b * b)
time = round(distance * 60 / s)    # multiply before dividing
# time = round(distance / s * 60)  # divide before multiplying
hour, minute = divmod(time, 60)
print(f"{hour:0>2}:{minute:0>2}")

Test case "Just a dream":
Found: 6631910462343143:28
Expected: 6631910462343144:32

I think it is that when you divide large numbers, there is a higher chance of a precision mistake. I edited your code to divide separately and it worked:

import math
a = float(input())
b = float(input())
s = float(input())
distance = math.hypot(a, b)
time_hours = distance / s
total_minutes = round(time_hours * 60)
hour, minute = divmod(total_minutes, 60)
print(f"{hour:02d}:{minute:02d}")
fixed
Your code performs the division (distance / s) first before multiplying (time_hours * 60). Try flipping the order around?
doesn't work because variable time_hours wouldn't be defined.

Try this:

distance_minutes = distance * 60
time_minutes = round(distance_minutes / s)

Alternatively, you can refer to my code above and switch the commented line with the uncommented line instead, it does the same thing.

Why do you want to do this way in the first place?
Also the code doesn't work when I plug it in and edit a bit.

I would think that the order of multiplication and division matters for floating point arithmetic. My idea is that first multiplying by 60 reduces the chances of floating point error in the calculation.

It actually increases because, well, multiplying then dividing creates a larger number than dividing then multiplying.
EX:
5*9/3
vs
5/3*9

The first one has a max value of 45 while the second one has a max value of 15

And for large numbers, there is a pretty significant difference.

That's exactly the issue with your code. For the test case "Just a Dream", if you add the following lines:

import sys
print(round(distance * 60 / s), file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
print(round(distance / s * 60), file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

You'll see different results printed to the console:
39791458087298936
39791458087298944

Removing the round() function reveals the underlying floating-point values:
3.9791458087298936e+16
3.979145808729894e+16

These values differ slightly due to floating-point precision limitations; specifically, the order of multiplication and division affects how rounding errors accumulate.

If you instead use the decimal.Decimal type for higher precision, the discrepancy disappears (even if you change the order of operations), and a consistent (but slightly different) value is returned:
39791458087298937

Key takeaways:

(a) Design test cases so that changes in the order of operations don't lead to inconsistent outcomes due to floating-point rounding.

(b) Design test cases so that precision-sensitive values are avoided.

For your reference, the code I used to test the decimal.Decimal type was written based on your original code:

from decimal import Decimal, getcontext
getcontext().prec = 50
a = Decimal(input())
b = Decimal(input())
s = Decimal(input())
distance = (a**2 + b**2).sqrt()
time_hours = distance / s
total_minutes = round(time_hours * 60)
hh = total_minutes // 60
mm = total_minutes % 60
print(f"{hh:02d}:{mm:02d}")
Works for me. How about you, @User123?
Yep, it works for me as well. Tested both operation orders with no conflict.
Can I change it to Ready now?
Based on your code, total minutes (an intermediate calculated value) exceed 2**53 for "Just a Dream" (test) and "Just a Dream.1" (validator). Please revise those cases.
What about now?

Total minutes still exceed 2**53. Add the following lines to your code for checking:

if total_minutes > (1 << 53):
    import sys
    print("exceeded", file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

I ran this code:
import math
a = float(input())
b = float(input())
s = float(input())
distance = math.sqrt(a**2 + b**2)
time_hours = distance / s
total_minutes = round(time_hours * 60)
if total_minutes > (1 << 53):
  import sys
  print("exceeded", file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
hh = total_minutes // 60
mm = total_minutes % 60
print(f"{hh:02d}:{mm:02d}")

And there were no outputting "exceeded"
Good. I think this was before our discussion of precision and back then you hadn't changed the cases yet.
So ready now?
Your call.
